column13: BHP executed a fixed-term (one year) agreement to introduce biofuels into the fuel mix for shipping of BHP's products for certain voyages, resulting in up to 19 per cent GHG emission reduction per voyage leg compared to conventional fuel (with the level of reduction depending on the bunkering specification). The biofuels used are certified under the International Sustainability and Carbon Certification system.

BHP pioneered real-time measurement, exchange and analysis of quality-assured voyage data with ship owners through DNV's Veracity data platform to enable BHP to optimise and introduce chartering choices as a strategic lever by selecting vessels with a comparatively lower GHG emission profile.

BHP prioritises structural reduction of its operational GHG emissions to achieve medium-term and long-term goals and fulfil its regulatory obligations. While BHP prioritises structural abatement, BHP acknowledges that carbon credits are likely to be needed to offset hard-to-abate GHG emissions with limited or no technological solution and in a temporary capacity as abatement options are being studied or to ensure compliance with local or regional GHG emission pricing schemes.
